column2: take the piss out of someone
column9: to make fun of someone; to tease someone.
column10: I have to make sure I get this right or they're all going to take the piss out of me mercilessly, because that's what English lads do.
column11: Are you taking the piss?
column12: It's the sort of English that people actually use.

column9: without mercy; without pity or kindness.
column10: I have to make sure I get this right or they're all going to take the piss out of me mercilessly, because that's what English lads do.
column11: This means 'without mercy'.
column12: If you add it to 'take the piss mercilessly' it means to do it with no mercy at all.

column6: Collocates with 'on' (to be lenient on someone)
column9: the opposite of strict; not as severe as expected.
column10: Some people thought they were lenient on me at the university but I think I was just working hard.
column11: The judge was accused of being too lenient on the car thieves.
column12: He was lucky to get quite a lenient sentence from the judge.

column9: A gerund form ('having' + past participle) that refers to an action that happened before the action of the main verb.
column10: You had this advantage of having had this difficult experience which was paying off for you.
column11: She has the advantage of having learned English as a child.
column12: I have the advantage of having been born in a developed country.

column9: to have something that helps you to be more successful than others.
column10: Hopefully my daughter will grow up to be bilingual, which means she should have the advantage of speaking two languages.
column11: You had this advantage of having had this difficult experience which was paying off for you.
column12: For me, I have the advantage of having grown up in an English speaking country.

column9: to result in benefits later.
column10: You had this advantage of having had this difficult experience which was paying off for you.
column11: I took the time to study grammar, and now it's paying off.
column12: If you work hard now, it'll pay off later.

column9: to become very pale, usually because of shock or fear.
column10: When I got the bad news I went white as a sheet.
column11: This just means that your face goes white, which can happen if you get a shock or bad news.
column12: Did you go white as a sheet?

column2: the blood drained from my face
column9: a way to say that you suddenly become very pale because of fear or shock.
column10: The blood drained out of my face.
column11: This, I suppose, is why your face goes white as a sheet.
column12: Did the blood drain from your face?

column9: feeling less confident or important; like all the air has gone out of you.
column10: I went back into my classroom, deflated, like a broken man.
column11: A person can be or feel deflated when they suddenly feel less important or less confident.
column12: When was the last time you felt deflated?

column9: to refuse an offer, request, or application.
column10: Thank you for your offer, but I'm afraid I'm going to turn it down.
column11: I'm sure I get turned down countless times because of my native language.
column12: My application was turned down.

column9: to go well with something else; to match.
column10: This tie complements that suit really well.
column11: The colours complement each other nicely.
column12: Native and non-native English teachers complement each other well.

column9: (verb) to say something positive to someone; to praise. (noun) a polite expression of praise or admiration.
column10: Everyone complimented me on my pronunciation.
column11: Being compared to Louis Theroux is a great compliment.
column12: It's very flattering to be paid so many compliments.

column9: praising or expressing admiration; also means 'given for free'.
column10: They made so many complimentary comments.
column11: All of our guests receive a complimentary bottle of wine.
column12: The adjective 'complimentary' can also mean 'given free'.

column9: achieved or experienced.
column10: You've got lots of episodes under your belt.
column11: I've got nearly 600 episodes under my belt.
column12: I've got about 18 years of English teaching under my belt now.

column9: to do something that you have been intending to do for a long time.
column10: Eventually I got round to doing it.
column11: Yesterday I finally got round to writing to my uncle and aunt.
column12: I haven't fixed the cupboard in the bathroom but I'll get round to it asap.

column9: praise and respect for an achievement.
column10: Kudos to you for being so respectful.
column11: It's 'much kudos', like 'much respect', or just 'kudos to him/her/you/them'.
column12: I'd like to give kudos to anyone who learns another language to fluency in adulthood.

column9: modest, not pretentious or arrogant.
column10: He's very unassuming, he's very nice.
column11: One of the things a lot of them said is that they preferred men who were unassuming.
column12: It means modest, but it also means that they're not assuming that anything will happen.

column9: to relax and stop being careful and defensive.
column10: When these people let their guards down, they show themselves for who they really are.
column11: If you let your guard down you might get punched!
column12: What does it take for you to let your guard down?

column9: a polite way to make a request, added to the end of an imperative.
column10: Describe the location of the Czech Republic, if you would.
column11: Hand me that stapler please, if you would.
column12: Fetch my coat, if you would.

column9: (of a country) surrounded by land with no coastline.
column10: We are a landlocked country.
column11: The Czech Republic is a completely landlocked country.
column12: Can you think of any landlocked countries?

column9: a long period of time when there is little or no rain.
column10: There was a terrible drought in summer here.
column11: Droughts cause water shortages and crop failures.
column12: Does your country suffer from droughts?

column9: to take part in an activity in a casual way, not seriously.
column10: I was just dabbling in teaching.
column11: Zdenek dabbled in teaching when he got back from his time in the UK.
column12: Have you dabbled in any of these things?

column9: to be remembered for a long time.
column10: Is there something that stuck with you from the dissertation you did?
column11: The film really stuck with me.
column12: He said something to me on my wedding day and it has stuck with me ever since.

column9: extremely good.
column10: A fantastic goal.
column11: That was an absolutely fantastic goal.
column12: It was a fantastic show.

column9: of the highest quality; grand; splendid.
column10: A superb challenge.
column11: That was an absolutely superb challenge by Maguire!
column12: The car's in superb condition.

column9: extremely beautiful, elaborate, or impressive.
column10: A magnificent free kick.
column11: And it was another magnificent free kick by Beckham.
column12: She looked magnificent in her wedding dress.

column9: having or showing impressive beauty or dignity.
column10: A majestic cross.
column11: It was a majestic cross there from Nigel.
column12: The majestic Rocky Mountains.

column9: astonishing or awe-inspiring in quality, so as to take one's breath away.
column10: A breathtaking start to the season.
column11: That was an absolutely breathtaking start to the season for Thompson.
column12: The view from the top of the mountain is breathtaking.

column9: someone or something that is very annoying or troublesome.
column10: It can be a pain in the neck, writing a masters degree.
column11: Having to do all this paperwork for my health insurance card is a real pain in the neck.
column12: He's such a pain in the neck.

column2: leave something until the last minute
column9: to delay doing something until the latest possible time.
column10: Some students left it until the last moment.
column11: I always leave things until the last minute.
column12: She left it until the last moment before preparing her presentation.

column6: Usually used in the negative form.
column9: to not have the right qualities or character for a particular job or activity.
column10: I went to a university of economics but I wasn't cut out for it.
column11: I gave up because I just wasn't cut out for the job.
column12: Have you ever tried something and given up because you just weren't cut out for it?

column9: to make a mistake; to do something wrong.
column10: I didn't want to mess up or otherwise my boss would tell me off.
column11: Oh no. I think I messed up. I forgot to switch off the oven.
column12: I completely messed up the recipe.

column9: to speak angrily to someone because they have done something wrong; to reprimand.
column10: I didn't want to mess up or otherwise my boss would tell me off.
column11: My boss told me off really badly last night.
column12: I got told off by my teacher for not doing my homework.

column9: to perform below expectations or standards.
column10: I thought I would underperform or I would never live up to my potential.
column11: England underperformed against Croatia and got knocked out of the World Cup.
column12: In fact, England usually underperform in international football tournaments.

column9: to fulfill expectations or a standard.
column10: I thought I would underperform or I would never live up to my potential.
column11: So, I never lived up to my potential, or their expectations of me.
column12: The first half seemed to suggest that this game would not live up to the anticipation.

column9: a person who is given all the boring, unpleasant jobs that no one else wants to do.
column10: I became a (general) dogsbody.
column11: I work in a hotel. I'm technically a porter but I'm also a general dogsbody.
column12: Have you ever worked as a general dogsbody?

column9: a small problem or temporary delay; also the sound you make when you have hiccups.
column10: Of course there were hiccups and times when I felt down.
column11: When you start up a new business there might be a few hiccups.
column12: The LEP app works pretty well, except for a few hiccups here and there.

column9: used to express that you are certain that something happened or was true in the past.
column10: It must have been in one of my episodes of ZEP. It must have been summer 2017.
column11: He must have been given the sack.
column12: It must have taken you ages!

column9: used to express that it's possible that something happened or was true in the past.
column10: He might have been given the sack.
column11: He could have been given the sack.
column12: He may have been given the sack.

column9: used to express that you are certain something did not happen or was not true in the past.
column10: He can't have been given the sack.
column11: He couldn't have been given the sack.
column12: It's impossible. He was the best teacher in the school. He can't have been given the sack.

column9: to give a particular impression.
column10: I think it came across quite well.
column11: He came across really badly in the interview.
column12: He just came across as defensive and unfriendly.

column9: the level or point at which something starts to happen or change. Also the floor of an entrance to a building.
column10: There's a threshold.
column11: If you get through those and keep going - you've passed the threshold into being a long-term LEPster.
column12: Do you have a high pain threshold?

column9: the quality of being the only one of its kind.
column10: You start to lose some uniqueness and you lose some edge.
column11: USP = unique selling point(s).
column12: What is the uniqueness of your project?

column9: an advantage over other people. Also the outer or furthest point of something.
column10: You start to lose some uniqueness and you lose some edge.
column11: Muhammad Ali's speed and footwork gave him a huge edge over his competitors.
column12: Don't go too close to the edge, you might fall off.

column9: to satisfy or fulfill all the necessary requirements.
column10: They've ticked all the right boxes.
column11: For example, the Mission Impossible films tick all the right boxes for me.
column12: Which films tick all the right boxes for you?

column9: in a similar way; something like that.
column10: I should do something along those lines too.
column11: Something along those lines, yes.
column12: Could you write something along the lines of 'If you don't deliver our package we will take further action'?

column6: Common false friend: does not mean 'now'.
column9: in fact; really.
column10: Where do you actually live?
column11: I just included this because I wanted to remind you that actually doesn't mean 'now'. It means in fact.
column12: Whereabouts do you live in your country, actually?

column9: approximately; about; around (used with numbers/figures).
column10: It could be somewhere in the region of 10,000 - 20,000 inhabitants.
column11: The UK has somewhere in the region of 66 million people.
column12: The population of my city is somewhere in the region of 2 million people.

column9: extremely unkind or severe (used for weather, criticism, conditions).
column10: We haven't had any harsh winters.
column11: An unusually harsh winter.
column12: The prisoners were subjected to harsh treatment.

column9: not severe or strong; gentle (used for weather, flavour, temperament).
column10: A surprisingly mild start to the year.
column11: We had a mild winter this year.
column12: He has a very mild temperament.

column9: uncomfortably hot.
column10: A particularly sweltering summer.
column11: It was a sweltering day in August.
column12: I can't sleep in this sweltering heat.

column9: to prevent someone from speaking or being heard by shouting loudly.
column10: 'We're not like these crazy conspiracy theorists who are going to shout you down.'
column11: She tried to explain her point of view but they all shouted her down.
column12: If I tried to say that English food was the best food in the world, would you shout me down?

column9: used to show that you think a word or phrase used to describe someone or something is not suitable or not true.
column10: They have all kinds of so-called evidence.
column11: It was one of his so-called friends that supplied him with the drugs that killed him.
column12: He calls them 'so-called' experts because he thinks they're not really experts.

column9: to investigate; to examine the facts about a problem or situation.
column10: These guys have been looking into it for a long time.
column11: The police are looking into the bank robbery.
column12: I'll look into it Luke.

column9: to force yourself not to laugh.
column10: (try to) suppress laughter while talking to them.
column11: You want to laugh, but you hold it in.
column12: Can you think of a time when you had to suppress laughter?

column9: to possess, own, hold, experience, or eat.
column10: I had the advantage of being taller than my classmates.
column11: I was having breakfast when the police knocked on my door.
column12: I always have a great time when I see my old friends.

column9: used with a past participle to form the perfect tenses.
column10: I have never visited Russia.
column11: Having visited Moscow a few times when I was young, I knew a few words of Russian.
column12: The school might have given him the sack.

column9: to be obliged to; must.
column10: I have to pick up my daughter at 5.30.
column11: It expresses obligation.
column12: You have to live your life up at the same level as their expectations.

column9: to express to someone your strong official disapproval of them.
column10: If you do something wrong and someone gets angry with you, and they reprimand you for it, it means that they tell you off.
column11: He was reprimanded by his boss for being late.
column12: She was reprimanded for her unprofessional behaviour.

column9: thought not to be completely true or honest; doubtful.
column10: They try to overwhelm me with all sorts of ideas based on very dubious so-called evidence.
column11: I'm dubious about his promises to change.
column12: These claims are dubious and not scientifically proven.

column9: (of a situation) not encouraging or hopeful; (of the weather) cold and miserable.
column10: An unusually bleak winter.
column11: The economic outlook is bleak.
column12: The house stands on a bleak, windswept hilltop.

column9: to start doing something with energy and determination.
column10: Are you ready to get stuck into some more English vocab and grammar?
column11: Let's get stuck into it.
column12: I need to get stuck into my homework.

column9: be patient with me.
column10: I know - this is quite a lot of grammar, but bear with me ok?
column11: If you'll just bear with me for a moment, I'll find you a copy.
column12: Please bear with me while I finish this phone call.

column9: to be rejected or refused for a job, application, or offer.
column10: I'm sure I get turned down countless times because of my native language.
column11: Have you ever applied for something and got turned down?
column12: I got turned down for a job once.

column9: to agree to or accept something.
column10: You really must go along with it if you want to be accepted.
column11: Go along with it and take the piss too.
column12: I'm not sure I can go along with that idea.

column9: feeling that you cannot trust other people and that they are trying to harm you.
column10: I didn't insult them or get angry, or call them paranoid and delusional nutters.
column11: He's getting paranoid about what other people are saying about him.
column12: You're just being paranoid.

column9: believing things that are not true.
column10: I didn't insult them or get angry, or call them paranoid and delusional nutters.
column11: Delusional people believe things that are not based in reality.
column12: He is suffering from delusional beliefs.

column9: a crazy or eccentric person.
column10: I didn't insult them or get angry, or call them paranoid and delusional nutters.
column11: He was a bit of a nutter, but harmless.
column12: Don't listen to him, he's a complete nutter.

column9: tending to deal with situations calmly and diplomatically; avoiding conflict.
column10: He's a documentary maker who is friendly and non-confrontational.
column11: He has a gentle, non-confrontational manner.
column12: I prefer a non-confrontational approach to solving problems.

column9: to work hard and steadily at something, especially something difficult.
column10: I will keep plugging away here, doing what I'm doing.
column11: She plugged away at her studies.
column12: If you keep plugging away, you'll finish the project eventually.

column9: very enthusiastic and eager to do something.
column10: Are you wide awake and raring to go?
column11: The players are raring to go for the final match.
column12: After a good night's sleep, I was raring to go.

column9: to be unable to stop giggling (laughing in a silly, uncontrolled way).
column10: For some reason my friends and I used to get the giggles.
column11: The students got the giggles during the serious play.
column12: It's hard not to get the giggles when he makes that funny face.

column9: to suddenly laugh a lot, or to make someone suddenly laugh a lot.
column10: This might make you snigger or maybe to crack up.
column11: The whole class cracked up when the teacher told the joke.
column12: He's so funny, he just cracks me up.

column9: to laugh in a quiet and disrespectful way.
column10: This might make you snigger or maybe to crack up.
column11: They sniggered at the teacher's old-fashioned clothes.
column12: I heard someone snigger behind me.

column9: to criticize someone in a severe and unkind way.
column10: I think he was a bit harsh on himself because honestly, there weren't that many mistakes.
column11: Don't be so harsh on him; he's only a child.
column12: The judges were very harsh on the new contestants.

column9: smooth, continuous, and unrestricted.
column10: ...highly functional bits of English that appeared even briefly, in my free-flowing conversation with Zdenek.
column11: It was a free-flowing discussion with many different ideas.
column12: The traffic was free-flowing this morning.

column9: the most modern and advanced stage of development in a particular type of work or activity.
column10: The company operates at the cutting edge of new technology.
column11: She's a designer who is always on the cutting edge of fashion.
column12: We are using cutting-edge technology to solve this problem.

column9: to do, say, or understand something correctly.
column10: I have to make sure I get this right or they're all going to take the piss out of me mercilessly.
column11: It's important to get the details right.
column12: I can't seem to get this recipe right.

column9: small problems that a new company, product, or system has in the beginning.
column10: When you start up a new business there might be a few hiccups - little errors, some teething problems when you begin.
column11: We've had a few teething problems with the new software, but it's working well now.
column12: Every new project has its teething problems.

column9: to resolve or settle small problems or difficulties.
column10: ...errors occurring in the system that need to be ironed out.
column11: We need to iron out a few details before we sign the contract.
column12: The meeting is a chance to iron out any disagreements.

column9: to be a natural part of your character.
column10: It's not in your nature to do it.
column11: It's not in her nature to be unkind.
column12: He's very competitive; it's just in his nature.

column9: to have the necessary qualities or abilities to succeed.
column10: You don't have what it takes to do it and you're not very good at it.
column11: She has what it takes to be a great leader.
column12: Do you think he has what it takes to win the championship?

column9: not what one likes or is interested in.
column10: He decided that it just wasn't his cup of tea.
column11: Thanks for inviting me, but action movies are not really my cup of tea.
column12: I know it's not everyone's cup of tea, but I enjoy classical music.

column9: a situation in which you have to do something very quickly.
column10: Sometimes it was a race against time to print the essay and hand it in on time.
column11: It was a race against time to finish the project before the deadline.
column12: The paramedics were in a race against time to save his life.

column9: the most important or powerful person in a group.
column10: The arrogant guys who will act like they're top dog or whatever.
column11: He quickly became the top dog in the company.
column12: Everyone wants to be the top dog.

column9: (of language) used in ordinary or familiar conversation; not formal or literary.
column10: It is unconventional and sounds very colloquial.
column11: 'Mate' is a colloquial term for a friend in British English.
column12: She uses a lot of colloquial expressions in her writing.
